article.title: Verification of STAR-Vote and Evaluation of FDR and ProVerif

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of these components does a voter **NOT** directly interact with in the STAR-Vote system, as depicted in Figure 1?
In the simplified STAR-Vote voting procedure shown in Figure 2, what does the message "Cv, P, ZPi" represent during the homomorphic tallying stage?
choices: Encrypted vote, proof, and hash chain value
Ballot identifier and ballot cast identifier
Public keys of the controller and trustee

multiple_choice_question.text: The authors mention that a key challenge in modeling STAR-Vote was handling the system\'s homomorphic tallying feature. How did they address this challenge in their formal models?
choices: They implemented a simplified version of homomorphic encryption within the models.
They abstracted away the homomorphic tallying and focused on individual vote decryption and public counting.
They used specialized model checking tools capable of verifying homomorphic encryption schemes.
They omitted the tallying process altogether, focusing solely on voter interaction with the voting terminal.

multiple_choice_question.text: The formal definition of vote-privacy presented in Definition 1 aims to ensure:
choices: All votes are correctly tallied and the final result reflects the will of the electorate.
An observer cannot determine which voter cast which vote, even if they can observe all communication.
Voters cannot be coerced into voting for a specific candidate or revealing their vote to a third party.
The voting system is resilient to attacks targeting the integrity of the ballot box and voting terminals.
